A. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Tip Top Poultry, Rockmart Facility, recognizes management's responsibility in protecting its employees, the public, the environment, equipment, and property.  The safety and health of all personnel are of primary importance.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the Rockmart facility.



To accomplish the company's goal in preventing accidents, the facility has established a Plant Safety Program.  The objectives of the Plant Safety Program are to: maximize safety performance, eliminate human suffering resulting from injuries and accidents and reduce losses associated with damage of property.



One of the activities associated with the Plant Safety Program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA's Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).  The Facility Manager is responsible for implementation of the Risk Management Program.



The purpose of the accidental release prevention and emergency response programs is to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.  Overall, these programs help prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses, environmental impacts and physical property damage.



The accidental release prevention and emergency response programs help prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, activities, and/or equipment.  These rules are detailed and improved as necessary.  They are also communicated to an

d accepted by all employees at the facility.



In addition to required safety programs, the Rockmart, GA facility has additional safety programs and process:



Corporate Safety Management System modeled after OSHAS 1800.

Central Safety Committee 

Hourly Safety Committees

Safety Audits conducted by both Salary and Hourly Employees

 

B. Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled



The Tip Top Poultry, Rockmart, GA facility is a chicken processing facility which receives processed chickens and prepares them for distribution via cutting and cooking, packaging, and then freezing them.  The facility operates two separate ammonia refrigeration systems to provide cooling and freezing capabilities for processing and storage areas.  The amount of anhydrous ammonia (CAS #7662-41-7) contained in the combined systems is in excess of 10,000 pounds.  The inventory in the Engine Room 1 system is approximately 14,700 pounds. The inventory in the Engine Room 2 system is approximately 9,300 pounds giving a combined total of 24,000 lbs.

  

The Engine Room 1 system is a High/Intermediate pressure system used to cool processes and workspaces throughout the facility.  The Engine Room 2 system is a Intermediate/Low pressure system used to cool docks and storage areas and provide refrigeration for Freezers operating down to -30 deg. F.



An ammonia release from the system poses a risk of offsite public and/or environmental injury or impact.  The system is regulated under the OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119).  The system is subject to the Program 3 requirements of the EPA's RMP (40 CFR Part 68) program.



C. Summary of Worst-Case and Alternative Release Scenarios



The worst-case release scenario at the facility for the ammonia refrigeration process involves the release of 16,669 pounds of ammonia over a 10 minute period due to the failure of the high pressure receiver (V-1) in the Engine Room 1 system when the entire system volume is pumped down to the V-1 and the co

nnected condensers.  This quantity represents the maximum quantity of ammonia in the receiver and condensers at any time.  Under worst-case weather conditions the toxic endpoint is 1.5 miles. This distance has been calculated based on the RMP Comp method provided in EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR 68) Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration.



The worst-case release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:



- The worst-case weather conditions which were used for this scenario are not typical and industry standards were followed for the manufacture and quality control of the receiver.  

- The receiver is located in a low traffic area within the engine room which minimizes the possibility of loss of containment due to vehicular impact (e.g., from forklifts etc.)

- Ammonia is not corrosive in this service and the vessel is relatively new.

- Pressure safety valves limit operating pressure in the receiver.

- The facility has a preventive maintenance program in place to maintain the on-going integrity of vessels.

- The facility has a training program designed to ensure that the system is operated by qualified personnel

- The facility emergency response procedures enable trained personnel to monitor levels and isolate any potential releases remotely using the control system or from a point a safe distance away from the release. 



The alternative release scenario for ammonia at the Rockmart, GA facility involves the release of ammonia through a defective pressure safety valve, which lifts to relieve high system pressure but fails to reseat properly (PSV) at a rate of 70 lbs/min.  Under alternative release weather conditions, the toxic endpoint is calculated by RMP Comp at .2 miles.  This distance has been calculated based on the method provided in EPA's Risk Management Program (40 CFR 68) Guidance for Ammonia Refrigeration using the RMP Comp program.



The alternative release scenario is unlikely for the following reasons:



- Industry standards were fo

llowed for the manufacture and quality control of the pressure relief devices.

- The system is operated at considerably lower pressures compared to the PSV's relief pressure setting.

- Ammonia is not corrosive in this service.

- The facility has a preventive maintenance program in place to maintain the on-going integrity of the pressure relief devices.

- The facility has a training program designed to ensure that the system is operated by qualified personnel.

- The facility emergency response procedures enable trained personnel to monitor levels and isolate any potential releases remotely using the control system or from a point a safe distance away from the release.



D. Description of the Accidental Release Prevention Program



The prevention program, which conforms to PSM/RMP requirements, consists of the following elements:



Employee Participation: This program involves the employees in establishing and implementing all aspects of the program.  Employees are involved when a process hazard analysis is conducted.  The program also ensures that all employees have complete access to the program.



Process Safety Information: Information has been collected which enables the employees to identify and understand the potential hazards in the refrigeration systems. The written information includes the ammonia SDS and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration systems.  Information is complete per the PSM/RMP requirements.



Process Hazard Analysis: Formal studies using the What-if and What-If/Checklist  Techniques have been conducted to examine the ammonia refrigeration system and identify potential hazards.  PHAs are reviewed on a five-year basis. Any recommendations made have been resolved or are in the process of being addressed.



Operating Procedures:  Written, detailed procedures have been developed which describe the steps which should be followed to safely operate the ammonia refrigeration system.  Procedures are reviewed annually and up

dated if necessary.



Training: A training program has been developed which ensures that employees are trained on all aspects of the system and on the duties which they should perform to ensure the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system. 



Contractors: All contractors are screened and evaluated before they perform work on or near the ammonia refrigeration systems.  All contractors coming into the facility are trained in evacuation procedures.  The contractors are also periodically evaluated to ensure that they perform work by following safe work practices.



Pre-Startup Safety Review: A pre-startup safety review is required for all new or modified ammonia refrigeration equipment and changes to the system.  The review verifies that all safety programs and procedures are in place, that training has been performed, and construction has been completed according to design standards before the project is put into use. They are also performed when there is a change in the process safety information.



Operating Procedures:  Standard Operating Procedures (SOP) are developed for each process covering all the equipment controls and process operations.  The SOPs are developed consistent with PSM/RMP requirements.



Mechanical Integrity:  This program ensures that the ammonia refrigeration systems are built and maintained using recommended and recognized preventive maintenance procedures to minimize unexpected breakdowns or failures.  Maintenance personnel are trained regularly and spare parts and maintenance supplies are used which are consistent with good engineering practices and manufacturer's recommendations.



Hot Work Permit: This permitting procedure for all hot work ensures that a signed permit is obtained prior to any cutting, welding, or burning; this indicates that all necessary precautions have been taken.



Management of Change: Procedures are designed to ensure that all changes made to the ammonia refrigeration systems are properly reviewed fo

r safety and against Best Engineering Practices criterion, that all the necessary and required information is obtained updated and that safety evaluations, e.g. PHA, have been performed.  This procedure works with the Pre-Startup Safety Review to ensure that any changes implemented are properly reviewed and managed.



Emergency Response:  An Emergency Plan has been developed and employees trained in reporting and responding to alarms and notifications of releases of ammonia.  The Plan and training includes evacuation procedures for all employees, visitors, and contractors. The Rockmart Fire Department was involved in the development of the plan. The Plan includes training and equipment for monitoring the levels from a safe distance and informing responders of hazards or changing conditions.



Incident Investigation: Procedures ensure that any incidents (and near misses) are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an investigation team. Any recommendations are resolved to improve the safety of the facility.  



Compliance Audits: There are procedures in place to conduct regular (3 year) audits of the PSM and RMP processes to ensure that the programs are in place and working properly.  Any recommendations made have been resolved or are in the process of being addressed. 



E.   Five-Year Accident History



There have been no reportable ammonia related incidents at the Tip Top Poultry Rockmart, Ga facility within the last five years.
